bestBHT.bht: After years of apostolic work, the apostle confesses that he no longer has an opportunity to continue his ministry in these regions. His strong desire to spread the gospel to those who have never heard it before intensifies his longing to see the Romans. Having established churches in every town and city, the apostle now looks to Spain as the next endeavor. The uncertainty of his liberation from imprisonment in Rome does not dampen his intense longing, affirming that the Gospel had been preached in Rome early on.

Henry Alford: I have no more place, or occasion...of apostolic work."

Respecting the question whether this journey into Spain was ever taken, the views of Commentators have differed, according to their conclusion respecting the liberation of the Apostle from his imprisonment at Rome.
I have discussed this in the Introduction to the Pastoral Epistles, §ii.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: these many years to come unto you
Albert Barnes: Having no further opportunity in these regions to preach to those who have never heard the gospel.
He had gone over them, had established churches, had left them in the care of elders.
Marvin Vincent: The primary meaning is sufficient, and hence comes to be applied to number and quantity; many, enough.
Worthy, i e., sufficient for an honor or a place.
Archibald T. Robertson: Surprising frankness that the average preacher would hardly use on such a matter.
A hapax legomenon, elsewhere επιποθησις (2 Corinthians 7:7; 2 Corinthians 7:11), from επιποθεω as in Romans 1:11.
'From considerable years.' So B C, but Aleph A D have πολλων, 'from many years.'
John Gill: He had fully preached the Gospel... had filled every town and city with it, had planted churches in every place, and ordained elders over them.
His proper work as an apostle being to preach the Gospel to all nations, and where Christ was not named, and to plant churches.
He had not only a desire, but a very vehement desire to come to them; he longed to see them... which shows that the Gospel had been preached very early at Rome.
John Wesley: Having no longer place in these parts — Where Christ has now been preached in every city.

bhtAttempts.bht: After years of apostolic work and a deep longing to come to the Romans, the apostle confesses that he no longer has a place or opportunity to continue his ministry in these regions. This surprising frankness reveals his strong desire to spread the gospel to those who have never heard it before. Having fully preached the Gospel and established churches in every town and city, he now looks to Spain as the next endeavor. Though the liberation of the apostle from his imprisonment in Rome remains uncertain, his intense longing to see the Romans affirms that the Gospel had been preached in Rome early on.

After years of apostolic work, the apostle confesses that he no longer has an opportunity to continue his ministry in these regions. His strong desire to spread the gospel to those who have never heard it before intensifies his longing to see the Romans. Having established churches in every town and city, the apostle now looks to Spain as the next endeavor. The uncertainty of his liberation from imprisonment in Rome does not dampen his intense longing, affirming that the Gospel had been preached in Rome early on.

After many years of apostolic work and a strong desire to come to the Romans, the apostle acknowledges that he has no further opportunity to continue his ministry in these regions. This surprising admission reveals his deep longing to spread the gospel to those who have never heard it before. Although the liberation of the apostle from his imprisonment in Rome remains uncertain, his intense longing to see the Romans confirms that the gospel had been preached in Rome early on. Now he looks towards Spain as his next mission, leaving behind the churches he had established.

After years of apostolic work and a strong longing to come to the Romans, the apostle frankly admits that he no longer has a place or opportunity to continue his ministry in these regions. This surprising confession highlights his intense desire to spread the gospel to those who have not yet heard it. Having established churches in every town and city, he now looks towards Spain as his next mission. While the exact circumstances of his release from imprisonment in Rome are uncertain, his longing to see the Romans affirms the early presence of the gospel in Rome.

After years of apostolic work, the apostle reveals his deep longing to come to the Romans, expressing that he no longer has the opportunity to continue his ministry in these regions. This surprising and frank admission demonstrates his strong desire to share the gospel with those who have not yet heard it. Having established churches and elders in every town and city, he now looks towards Spain as his next endeavor. Despite the uncertainty of his release from imprisonment in Rome, his intense longing confirms the early presence of the gospel in Rome.
